Identifying Characteristics: Approximately 30 species of freshwater sponges in North America

Sponges are unique multicellular aquatic animals, lacking muscular tissue, a central nervous system, and internal organs.  Lacking the differentiation of tissue found in most animals, individual sponge cells segregate to perform specific roles related to feeding, reproduction, etc.
Sponge shapes vary widely; may appear as flattened "paint-splats", soft mounds, coating on submersed branches, or intricate coral-like structures.
Bright green to brownish in color
Biology: Most sponges reproduce sexually and are generally hermaphroditic, having male and female germ cells in one animal.  Asexual reproduction also occurs; having the ability to regenerate from a small fragment, freshwater sponges can multiply when fractured by disturbance

Microscopic larvae are released into the water, and are free swimming for a short period before descending to a surface where they attach and metamorphose into young sponges.  Once a attached, they become sessile (fixed in one place; immobile)

Sponges are filter feeders. Water is taken in through numerous microscopic pores on the internal channels allows the sponge to filter out, and feed upon, the tiny free-floating aquatic organisms in the water, such as protozoans and bacteria

When exposed to excess cold or other harsh conditions, sponges form hardy bud-like structures called gemmules, which can survive in a dormant state.  When conditions improve, the gemmules metamorphose into a new sponge.
Habitat: Submersed on rocks, plant stems, pieces of wood, and other firm substrates
